page.title: 02THE LANDSCAPE OF DALRY(KIRK)
page.content: This area is a landscape modified by man. It is mainly a valley connecting two lochs, Earlstoun, a man-made area of water to the north and Loch Ken with its artificially raised water level in the south .The valley between, is that of a glacially formed infilled trough which is the flood plain of the Water of Ken.This river flows in a valley one kilometer wide in a series of meanders contained within levees which are partly man made. Prone to flooding, this stretch of river has a gradient of no more than 1 in 150. Tributary streams flow into the Ken from the eastern edge of the Rhinns of Kells. The valley sides, made of greywacke cut by dolomite dykes, form gently rounded hills plastered with glacial drift often in the form of drumlins.
